See also: Lachen

Crimean Gothic[edit]

Etymology[edit]

From Proto-Germanic *hlahjaną.

Verb[edit]

lachen

  1. to laugh
    • 1562, Ogier Ghiselin de Busbecq:
      Lachen. Ridere.

Dutch[edit]

Etymology[edit]

From Middle Dutch lachen, from Old Dutch *lahhan, from Proto-Germanic *hlahjaną.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /ˈlɑxə(n)/
  • Audio
    		(file)
  • Hyphenation: la‧chen

Verb[edit]

lachen

  1. (intransitive) to laugh

Inflection[edit]

Inflection of lachen (weak with strong past participle)

past participlegelachen

gerundlachen n

imperative plur.1lacht
participleslachendgelachen
1) Archaic.

Derived terms[edit]

  • schaterlachen
  • aanlachen
  • uitlachen

German[edit]

Etymology[edit]

From Middle High German lachen, from Old High German lahhen, from Proto-Germanic *hlahjaną.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • audio (Austria)
    		(file)
  • IPA(key): [ˈlaχn̩]
  • Audio
    		(file)
  • Rhymes: -aχn

Verb[edit]

lachen (third-person singular simple present lacht, past tense lachte, past participle gelacht, auxiliary haben)

  1. to laugh

Conjugation[edit]

er lachtesie lachtener lachtesie lachten
imperativelach (du)
lache (du)		lacht (ihr)

Low German[edit]

Etymology[edit]

From Middle Low German lachen, from Old Saxon hlahhian, from Proto-Germanic *hlahjaną.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /ˈlaxːən/

Verb[edit]

lachen (past singular lach, past participle lacht, auxiliary verb hebben)

  1. to laugh

Conjugation[edit]

Conjugation of lachen (weak verb)
infinitivelachen
indicativepresentpreterite
1st person singularlachlach
2nd person singularlachs(t)lachs(t)
3rd person singularlach(t)lach
plurallacht, lachenlachen
imperativepresent—
singularlach(e)
plurallacht
participlepresentpast
lachen(e)lacht, gelacht
Note: This conjugation is one of many; neither its grammar nor spelling apply to all dialects.

Derived terms[edit]

  • anlachen
  • grifflachen
  • utlachen

Middle Dutch[edit]

Etymology[edit]

from Old Dutch *lahhan, from Proto-Germanic *hlahjaną.

Verb[edit]

lachen

  1. to laugh
  2. to smile
  3. to be happy

Inflection[edit]

This verb needs an inflection-table template.

Descendants[edit]

  • Dutch: lachen
  • Limburgish: lache

  • “lachen (II)”, in Vroegmiddelnederlands Woordenboek, 2000
